item.title: Car or Motorbike?
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

Mopman:

Tbh, clutching up the front wheel is way easier to fuck up than a powerwheelie, but unfortunately most people won’t be sitting on a bike powerful enough for a long while. Finally I’m derestricted in september, but I don’t have 18k euros

Lol[quote=“Secet, post:39, topic:85385”][quote author=kmb link=topic=125204.msg1253496#msg1253496 date=1178123872]

You people are all pussies. You you can ride bikes in the winter too, y’know.

Bikes > Cars. I find it rather amusing when i blast past cars that cost the owner £10,000+ on my shitheap that cost me £200. The owner of the car tends to find it less amusing.

Ma’god, winter in the UK is pussy. Here in Finland, where the real men live, we drive with our bikes through inches of snow every day four months a year.

On topic, I prefer cars.

[/quote]

Yea you can easily ride trough winter, that’s what I did. Just get good tires and it’s almost like in summer (not really).
But if you wanna go trough winter, you can do that with sportbikes ofcourse, just buy some cheap enduro I’m planning to buy some old Kawasaki enduro for next winter and sell it forward in spring. After I’m 18 I will probably buy KTM 450 EXC, so awesome bike.

And when I get that KTM I will try to learn how to do a wheelie. :)[/quote]
l2motorbike. Get a Yamaha you clutz

Read full topic

item.title: Car or Motorbike?
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

[quote=“Waffendennis, post:37, topic:85385”]If I have to chose it would be a bike for me.

Sure I love my car, but nothing can match the experience of a sports bike, the speed experience is just different than in a car.

If I drive 120+ km/h in a car it doesn’t feel special at all, but if you do that on a bike it’s totally different, you don’t got any protection like a car has to offer you, so the thrill you get from that is just different.

Also the price of a bike, for around 18k euro you have a Yamaha R1.
The R1 (if you get the propper mods installed such as turbo) is faster than most exotic cars, in acceleration wise, and on some cars top speed too.

Ok I have to admit, you don’t want to go 320 km/h with a bike, it’s just scary as hell knowing that just a slight bump on the road can make you go airborn and end your life for sure.

The expierence of driving a sports bike can’t be compared with that of a car though.

Btw, for those people scared of pulling a wheely, just change gears intime and don’t rev the engine too much so that the engine comes into it’s full powerband.

And if you want to pull wheelies and your bike doesn’t do it by it self then do this:
1: Grip the clutch
2: Rev the engine up to around 8-9k RPM (depends on the engine of your bike!!! DON’T DO THIS WITH A LOW POWERED BIKE, IT’LL HARM YOUR ENGINE! if you got a low power bike such as a 125cc for example, rev the engine until you think the engine gives the most power)
3: Compress the fore fork by slightly pulling the front brake
4: Let go of the clutch and the front brake
5: And your front wheel gets airborn

(Don’t give full throttle btw! it’ll result in you crashing :D).

If you think you’re going to fall backwards just leave of the throttle and if needed use the rear brake, but don’t slam the pedal because your wheel will lock and this will resulting into a crash too :D.

PS:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=S-ppGiwc0wQ < The Turbo mod I’m talking about, this mod turns the R1 into a suicide machine that keeps making power wheelies)

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WShY1ObPvhQ&mode=related&search= < Exotic cars (Bugatti Veyron!!) vs R1 ;)[/quote]
That 1-5 steps is nearly the exact same technique used when coming of the gate in a race.
But, on a 125cc two-stroke, 8-9k is plenty, it would result in wheel spin. For me, I live by 4 steps when I wheelie.

  1. Be in 1st or 2nd gear. (depends on the traction I guess)
  2. Pop the clutch, (pull it in quickly and let it out) The front starts to rise. While throwing my weight onto the backwheel.
  3. Feather the clutch, (fan it, like pull it in 2 cm’s)
  4. Shift when needed, while still feather the clutch, with my foot over the back break.

Read full topic

item.title: Car or Motorbike?
item.dc:creator: @Waffendennis Waffendennis
item.description:
@Waffendennis wrote:

If I have to chose it would be a bike for me.

Sure I love my car, but nothing can match the experience of a sports bike, the speed experience is just different than in a car.

If I drive 120+ km/h in a car it doesn’t feel special at all, but if you do that on a bike it’s totally different, you don’t got any protection like a car has to offer you, so the thrill you get from that is just different.

Also the price of a bike, for around 18k euro you have a Yamaha R1.
The R1 (if you get the propper mods installed such as turbo) is faster than most exotic cars, in acceleration wise, and on some cars top speed too.

Ok I have to admit, you don’t want to go 320 km/h with a bike, it’s just scary as hell knowing that just a slight bump on the road can make you go airborn and end your life for sure.

The expierence of driving a sports bike can’t be compared with that of a car though.

Btw, for those people scared of pulling a wheely, just change gears intime and don’t rev the engine too much so that the engine comes into it’s full powerband.

And if you want to pull wheelies and your bike doesn’t do it by it self then do this:
1: Grip the clutch
2: Rev the engine up to around 8-9k RPM (depends on the engine of your bike!!! DON’T DO THIS WITH A LOW POWERED BIKE, IT’LL HARM YOUR ENGINE! if you got a low power bike such as a 125cc for example, rev the engine until you think the engine gives the most power)
3: Compress the fore fork by slightly pulling the front brake
4: Let go of the clutch and the front brake
5: And your front wheel gets airborn

(Don’t give full throttle btw! it’ll result in you crashing :D).

If you think you’re going to fall backwards just leave of the throttle and if needed use the rear brake, but don’t slam the pedal because your wheel will lock and this will resulting into a crash too :D.

PS:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=S-ppGiwc0wQ < The Turbo mod I’m talking about, this mod turns the R1 into a suicide machine that keeps making power wheelies)

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WShY1ObPvhQ&mode=related&search= < Exotic cars (Bugatti Veyron!!) vs R1

item.title: Car or Motorbike?
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

[quote=“Yz85Racer, post:32, topic:85385”][quote author=Mopman link=topic=125204.msg1259932#msg1259932 date=1178249893]
A 2-stroke powerband isn’t too hard to deal with if you’re careful with the throttle while you’re learning clutch control anyway, besides, going over the back of your bike is a great reminder never to do that again
[/quote]
I’ve done that. Never again lol, first time I was on a two-stroke with a powerband(65) I was used to a 50, fanged into it, and pumped me over the back of it. Never again will I ride a two-stroke like a four-stroke. Though, I ride with a finger on the clutch, so if it does decide to want to wheelie on me, I just pull the clutch in, maybe slightly ease the back break.[/quote]

Haha, yeah it’s pretty crazy. I’m scared to get a bigger bike for the road at the moment tbh, because I know I’ll flip it as soon as I get cocky and the wheelies start getting higher… at least with my piece of crap at the moment it will only lift a foot or 2 anyway heh.

Read full topic

item.title: Car or Motorbike?
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

Mopman:

A 2-stroke powerband isn’t too hard to deal with if you’re careful with the throttle while you’re learning clutch control anyway, besides, going over the back of your bike is a great reminder never to do that again

I’ve done that. Never again lol, first time I was on a two-stroke with a powerband(65) I was used to a 50, fanged into it, and pumped me over the back of it. Never again will I ride a two-stroke like a four-stroke. Though, I ride with a finger on the clutch, so if it does decide to want to wheelie on me, I just pull the clutch in, maybe slightly ease the back break.

item.title: Car or Motorbike?
item.dc:creator: @rabcarl rabcarl
item.description:
@rabcarl wrote:

[quote=“Yz85Racer, post:23, topic:85385”][quote author=rabcarl link=topic=125204.msg1246761#msg1246761 date=1177997661]

It depends on where you live, here in ohio where it is cold half the year only having a motorcycle would not be practical, you have to have some type of car or truck for the winter, then if you want to ride a motorcycle in the summer you can.

I will leave you with these wise words of advice:

If you get a car, make sure its a mopar. ;D

Chevy chevelle/el camino/nova FTW?
I like mopar also, basically any muscle car, newer cars are gay… all the geo prizms, mini vans, etc… a few new cars are ok i guess but when you could get a car thats just as fast and looks about 100x cooler for less than half the price…

Getting a bike isn’t that hard, just go to a local swap meet, pick up an old enduro or dirtbike and put on headlights and blinkers for about $150-200 and you’re good
[/quote]
I suggest you not do that. If you’re saying go pick up a bike, and put headlights on. Not a good idea, well, it can be, but be sure not to pick up a two-stroke. If you’ve never rode before, cause the powerband :/[/quote]
Ya my friend is so lucky he got a kawasaki 350 for $200 at a swap meet last year… lucky bastard

Read full topic
